bibl.title: Book Review: William Crawford Gorgas, His Life and Work, by the Editor of the The Military Surgeon, March 1925

div1.p: This editorial concerns Marie Gorgas' biography of her husband. The editor comments on the claims made concerning Gorgas' yellow fever work.

div1.head: Book Review: William Crawford Gorgas, His Life and Work, by the Editor of the The Military Surgeon, March 1925
div1.p: (Reprinted from The Military Surgeon for March, 1925)

There recently came to the editorial desk a most interesting and
attractive story of the life of one who, if not one of the world's great
men, certainly accomplished great things in the world. There are
few readers of books, we opine, who will be so simple or so unreason-
able as to expect a plain, unvarnished tale from the combined author-
ship of a devoted wife and the editor of a popular magazine, and there-
fore we are not surprised or aggrieved to find a portrait of high lights
with few lines and shadows, and in which no faults or imperfections
appear through the shining gloss of love and hero worship. How the
“gaunt specter of yellow fever” confronted Gorgas at every stage of
his career is well told, and how also this portentous destroyer was to
him a friend in disguise to whom he owed wife, opportunity, fame and
great place, and the personal immunity which enabled him to walk
without fear in the shadow of death.

The human story of his parents, his boyhood, his courtship and
marriage and his army career up to the time when, in 1899, he became
the Chief Surgeon, Department of Havana, is charmingly told. Here
he enters the limelight and the zone of historical interest where it
would have been advisable for the narrators to check memories with
the records and, in making claims for him, to be mindful of those of
others. Here, therefore, the conscientious reviewer must take note of
omissions and errors which are misleading and out of place in an his-
torical biography.

The story of the cleaning up of Havana, which is here completely
credited to Gorgas, is one in which there are in fact many overlapping
claims. These will not be gone into further than to remark that the
streets, which are so graphically described on page 85 as paved with
garbage and dead cats, were never at any time under Gorgas but were
in charge of the Street Cleaning Department under the efficient direc-
tion of Major William M. Black, U. S. Eng. Corps, later Major
General and Chief of Engineers. The police of the buildings and
patios where the Engineer Department did not have the right of entry
was under Major Davis, the Sanitary Officer, who reported directly to
General Ludlow and was not under the Chief Surgeon, Major Gorgas,
during all the year 1899 or up to the time when Davis was ordered
to the Philippines in February, 1900. From our authors' account of

“the good scouring and good bath” which Gorgas said to himself he
would give the “rotting city,” one would never guess that the scouring
and bathing had been going on energetically for over a year before
he had a chance at the scrubbing brush.

But the central interest of the story revolves about the conquest
of yellow fever and the share which several men had in that mighty
accomplishment, and here, too, the careful reader is distressed to find
a like looseness of statement and dearth of dates.

As is always the case in great deeds, many men contribute to make
it possible, and it might not be easy even in a scientific work to evalu-
ate their several donations, but three men stand out in the center of the
stage, Finlay, the prophet, to whom none would listen, Reed, the
scientific demonstrator, whom none but the blind could fail to follow,
and Gorgas, the brave and pertinacious administrator, whom no
obstacle could turn aside. Behind these in the second rank stand
Reed's assistants, Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte, and H. R. Carter
whose valuable observation of extrinsic incubation was an unsolved
puzzle until Reed furnished the key. The story is, as our authors say,
an intensely dramatic one, and as is usual in dramas it is divided into
acts. The first act from the pronouncement of the mosquito theory
by Finlay in 1881 to the entrance of Reed in July, 1900, covers a
period of 19 years. The second act, the demonstration by Reed was
finished in six months. Then there was an intermission of six weeks
or two months occupied in the conversion of Gorgas before the
beginning of practical application of Reed's demonstration by warfare
against the mosquito in Havana. Then the curtain rises for the last
act which lasted until May, 1906, when Panama was at length freed
from yellow fever.

The attitude of Gorgas was very conservative and his conversion
slow, as was the rule with those who had much experience with
yellow fever. He was sufficiently convinced of the mosquito theory to
begin its practical application on the first of March, 1901, and he then
cleaned up Havana as far as mosquitos were concerned. He did not,
however, yet accept in practice the harmlessness of fomites such as
bedding, clothing, etc., which Reed had demonstrated with equal
conclusiveness, and he continued these useless and expensive disinfec-
tions until the middle of August, 1901, although the Chief Surgeon,
Department of Cuba, Colonel Havard, had directed in April that mili-
tary surgeons desist from them. The acceptance of Reed's conclusions
by the other medical officers in Cuba was immediate, and the applica-
tion of them by those having sanitary responsibilities, began at once.
The Chief Surgeon of Western Cuba who was in intimate daily con-
tact with Reed began operations against mosquitos on October 15,

1900, convinced (as was General Wood) by the cases of Carroll,
Lazear and the cavalryman X. Y. On December 21, 1900, General
Wood issued General Order No. 6 of the Department of Cuba which
stated that “the Chief Surgeon has reported that it is now well estab-
lished that malaria, yellow fever and filarial infection are transmitted
by mosquitos,” and directed the protection of the troops at all posts by
mosquito bars and the use of petroleum for the destruction of mosquito
larvae in water barrels, fire buckets, post holes, old cans, cesspools
or undrained puddles.

Our authors picture (page 110 et seq.) the mental attitude of Reed
and other scientists towards the mosquito theory in the early months
of 1901 as one of pessimism and depression. They thought that the
discovery was academic and did not see how it greatly lessened the
general yellow fever peril! Nothing could be further from the truth.
The dread of the unknown was dispelled and the general feeling was
one of elation and great relief. While Gorgas still hesitated, the post
surgeons went to work, under Reed's inspiration and General Wood's
orders, with oil can and spade and hoe. Military sanitarians had
already learned how to attack the mosquito from the writings of Dr.
L. O. Howard (Chief of the Bureau of Entomology), and we find
Reed writing to that distinguished scientist on January 13, 1901, in a
gale of joy that “with Howard and Kerosene we would soon knock out
old culex fasciatus” as the yellow fever mosquito was then called.
Trifles often shed an interesting light on current events and the
writer's diary recalls that on a Christmas tree at Columbia Barracks
in 1900, gotten up by two ladies of the post for the children and a
few of their elders, Reed's gift was a wonderful stegomyia made of
champagne cork with a formidable probosis, and tooth pick legs
beautifully banded, while Dr. Amador, the post sanitary officer,
received a can of kerosene as his badge of office with doggerel verses
describing the pursuit of the mosquito.

Fortunately, however, for the fame of Gorgas, ill-founded claims
of priority and originality are not necessary to round out the great-
ness of his achievement either at Havana or later at Panama.

His difficulties in Panama due to the lack of support or open hos-
tility of his immediate superiors cannot fail to excite the surprise and
indignation of the reader, and we are pleased to see the punishment
which the “Old Man of the Sea” had so richly earned by his obstinacy
and ignorance. It is not, however, accurate to say that Dr. C. A. L.
Reed, who came to Gorgas' rescue in his heart-breaking struggle with
the first Commission, was sent down by the American Medical Asso-
ciation. He went at the request of the Secretary of War, Mr. Taft,
and it was to the Secretary that his report was made, although he did

violate the proprieties by slipping a copy of it to the editor of the A.
M. A. Journal.

It is a similar fact, and one which though it is shown, is not ex-
plained in the biography, that so gentle and kindly a person as Gorgas
did not enjoy the support but rather the opposition of so many of
the chiefs under whom he served at Panama, as Walker, Shonts, Ma-
goon, Wallace and Goethals. Yet they were not all “Old Men of
the Sea.” Whatever the cause may be it brings out the quality
which was the dominant and winning one in his career, the patient
persistence with which he pursued his aims, and the far point on which
he held his vision fixed, to the exclusion from his mind of the diffi-
culties and annoyances which beset his path, and which like his own
familiar stegomyia buzzed about his head or bit his ankles. Our
sense of justice regrets the absence from the copious index of the names
of some of those whose friendly aid saved him in critical periods of
his career, as General Fitzhugh Lee, who when Gorgas was relieved
from duty in Havana and ordered first to Santiago, and then to Lee's
own staff in April, 1900, secured a revocation of the order. And
though Dr. Lambert's intervention in his behalf is well told, no men-
tion is made in this book of the constant assistance and loyal sup-
port given Gorgas at every step by his own Chief, Surgeon General
O'Reilly, a support which was often invoked and never failed him, and
which enabled him to move steadily onward against wind and tide.
It was well known in the Surgeon General's Office that on at least
one occasion General O'Reilly's intercession with the Secretary of
War saved Gorgas from recall from Panama.

Between the ratification of peace with Spain and our entry into
the World War, eighteen years passed, during which General Gorgas
saw no service with troops and gave but little time to military matters.
During the three years that he was Surgeon General before the latter
date he was much more occupied with the organization of the Inter-
national Health Board, the cleansing of South America, and the other
details of his lofty dream of the extinction of yellow fever, than with
the complexities of medico-military organization. By what gift of
genius or what great stroke of luck did he then succeed in meeting
the vast responsibilities of the World War? The secret of his success
appears to deserve mention in the story of his life and his work. It
is the story of General O'Reilly and his successor, General Torney, and
the devoted and united band of their assistants, who year by year
labored to make good the errors of the Spanish War, to consolidate
and organize, to train and prepare and make ready plans, personnel
and matériel. Thus Gorgas, when he returned from his long sojourn
in South America and found war facing the country, found a medical
Editorial
5
corps enlarged, united, trained and eager, awaiting with confidence the
day of trial. There may have been in his heart some misgivings as to
his ability to handle this complex machine, or some doubt as to his
physical ability to stand the impending strain, for early in 1917 he
sounded the Secretary of War as to retirement. The rupture of
diplomatic relations with Germany intervened to prevent the grati-
fication of this wish and he braced himself for the shock, and guided
as best he could the multitudinous activities of the Medical Corps and
the medical profession in these two crowded and eventful years.

It is not easy to evaluate the contribution of Gorgas to the splen-
did effort of the Medical Service in the World War. He was now at
the height of his fame and his popularity was great with Congress
and throughout the country. This made it easy for him to obtain
the legislation which was necessary, and greatly assisted the operation
of the machinery which had been already prepared for the enrollment
of the civilian practitioners. He drew about him the leaders of the
medical profession and was liberal in the delegation of his authority.
He wisely left a large initiative to the trained men under him. He
was active in inspections and tireless in conferences. To say that this
constituted the sum of his effort would be doubtless an understatement
but not a greater assault upon our sense of proportion than is made
by our authors in their advancement of a general claim for the credit
of the entire medical achievement. With the service in France it is
certain that the Surgeon General had little to do. “In France he
provided accommodations for 25 per cent of the American soldiers in
the field. He constructed one hospital with 27,000 beds,” are state-
ments which can hardly be accepted even in a Pickwickian sense. It
is doubtful if he ever heard the name of Mesves until that hospital
city had already spread itself over the vineyards of Saone-et-Loire.
It would be as just or as unjust to fix on him the responsibility for
the costly errors committed in France with regard to the Medical
Department, such as cutting down the medical personnel in France to
one-half of that estimated as needful by the Chief Surgeon, or the
production of pneumonia by order by the restriction of the air space
in billets and hospitals, as to credit him with the work of the Chief
Surgeon A. E. F.

Suffice it to say that when General Gorgas visited us in France
in the stirring days of September, 1918, his rôle was not that of
Hector in the field, but rather that of Priam at the Scaean Gate.

It is pleasant to read in the final chapter of the honours and
decorations and royal attentions which brightened the end of his fine
and useful career, and the noble and fitting funeral at St. Paul's by
which the British Government paid a final tribute to his memory.
